regret.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to feel sorry about something you have done and wish you had not done it
regret.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Don’t do anything you might regret.
I regret leaving school so young.
He was beginning to regret that he’d come along.
regret.translation[0].definitions[1].def: used in official letters or statements when saying that you are sorry or sad about something
regret.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: We regret any inconvenience caused to our customers.
I regret to inform you that your contract will not be renewed.
I regret that I will be unable to attend.
regret.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: I deeply regretted what had happened.
I bitterly regretted my decision to leave.
The airline sincerely regrets any delays to passengers.
We very much regret that there will be job losses.
‘No, ’ she blurted out, instantly regretting her response.
If you don’t go, you may live to regret it.
regret.translation[1].definitions[0].def: sadness that you feel about something, especially because you wish it had not happened
regret.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: She has already expressed deep regret for what happened.
I have no regrets about leaving.
I decided with some regret that it was time to move on.
It is with great regret that I must decline your offer.
I lost touch with her, much to my regret.
regret.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: I accepted his resignation with great regret.
To the bitter regret of his party, he refused to call an election.
Her biggest regret was not having children.
My only regret is that my parents did not live to see this day.
The president expressed his regret at the deaths.
Kate watched her go with a pang of regret.
